intro: Helianthus ovatus, commonly known as the swamp sunflower, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its yellow-orange petals and a distinctive, elongated flower head that resembles a sunflower. The plant typically grows in wetland habitats, such as swamps and marshes, and thrives in moist, well-drained soils. Its leaves are lance-shaped and often have a hairy texture, while its stems are sturdy and upright. Helianthus ovatus plays an important role in supporting local pollinators, including bees and butterflies.
